titleStmt.title: J. R. Duncan et al. to Beriah Magoffin
CWG9243

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p:
To his Excellency Beriah Magoffin
Govenor of the Commonwealth of Ky.

Your Petitioners represent to your Excellency That at the Jany ^Dec.^ term of the Barren County Equity & Criminal Court and John Kenady were tried and ^1858^ confined to the Penitentiary of this state for the term of 4 years upon a charge of having shot at and wounding his wife Mary Jane Kenady with intent to kill. They state that said Kenady had been married but a few months & that he & his wife were going home from a neighbors House on Sunday evening some three quarters of a mile from home and that the shooting was done in the Road Public Road some quarter of a mile from home about dusk or a little before about 3/4 rom hour after dark dark to one else being present but he and his wife The Proof for the defense showed that no motive existed or that there ever had been any difficulty between them but that they had lived together Peacible and at the house of his fathers time after their marriage. That he now had had a Pistol in his life that he was always an inoffensive harmless boy. That very soon before the shooting was done W. K. Mayen passed the road when it was done about Dusk and saw and heard an object behind a log and after the occurence went and examined the Plase & that it looked like some
person had laid behind it if some person were also seen near the spot behind a tree His wife Mary Jane Kenady stated that at the time she received the shot she saw no person & heard no one except her husband & if he did not do it. She does not knew who did that at the time she received the shot her husband steped a little behind her to avoid a mud Hole in the road was all she knew about it she stated he had always treated her kindly & that she knew of no cause or motive. Your Petitioners represent & state that from all the facts and circumstances in the case they think it is a case which is well worthy the Executive Clemency to which end they entreat & pray your excellency

J R Duncan M D.
Ben McIntire
J. A. Goodall
J. W. Vetch Newman
J. C. McClelin
Hines Smith
John M Bishop
Wm. J. Fletcher
T C Johnson
